newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Sweden stadium blast, no link to Olympic bid seen.
newsitem.headline: Sweden stadium blast, no link to Olympic bid seen.

text.p: A mysterious explosion early on Friday which damaged the Stockholm stadium which hosted the 1912 Olympics was not connected to the city's bid to host the 2004 Games, a campaign official said.
"There is no evidence that the explosion in the 1912 Stockholm Stadium has anything to do with the current Olympic bid," said Olof Stenhammar, president of the Stockholm bid committee.
Residents in the inner Stockholm neighbourhood where the stadium is located were woken up by an explosion at about 1.00 am local time (2300 GMT), police inspector Harreet Leeftam said.
Police on a routine patrol in the area arrived at the stadium almost immediately and searched the area with dogs, but no suspects were found, she said.
No injuries were reported from the explosion, which left a gaping hole in the roof above the main entrance on the eastern side of the arena.
Most heavily damaged were the stadium public address booth and press boxes, police spokesman Claes Cassel said.
The police had no leads, he said.
By early afternoon, maintenance men closed off the stadium where some of athletics' biggest stars have set world records.
Glass littered the stadium's all-weather track. Tiles blown off the roof were strewn across the pavement inside the stadium gate.
Security at the stadium is minimal with only a 1.5-metre (five ft) wrought-iron fence for protection.
If Stockholm wins the 2004 Games, the stadium is scheduled to be used for some equestrian and modern pentathlon events but not as the main arena.
Arsonists have struck seven sports venues in Stockholm since May.
All the fires, which police believe may be connected, have occurred at night but Cassel said no person or group has claimed responsibility for any of the fires.

"There has been absolute silence," he said. "If the person or persons responsible have a special aim, it's most likely they would tell in some way. Since they haven't done this, you wonder what is going on."
Stockholm is competing with Athens, Buenos Aires, Cape Town and Rome to stage the 2004 Olympics. The decision will be made on September 5.
